II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
At  the  request  of  the  Government  of  Tajikistan,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
approved a TA1 to prepare an agriculture rehabilitation project. The project preparatory TA was 
carried  out  from  February  to  July  2001  and  built  upon  the  previously  completed  Agriculture 
Sector Assessment Study.2 This document is based on the consultants’ reports, the findings of 
the  missions,  and  discussions  with  national  and  local  government  agencies,  potential  project 
beneficiaries, and nongovernmental organizations, particularly those held during the roundtable 
discussions in Dushanbe on 8 and 9 October 2002. Project framework is in Appendixes 1. 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Tajikistan has a population of 6.1 million with a growth rate of 1.7% per annum and an 
3. 
average  life  expectancy  of  64.  About  73%  of  the  population  live  in  rural  areas  and  18%  of 
households have a female as head of the family. As a result of the termination of fiscal transfers 
and sharp decline in agricultural productivity, rural incomes have plunged over the past decade. 
The  agriculture  sector  is  estimated  to  employ  52%  of  the  workforce  but  unemployment  and 
underemployment levels are high. On average, at least 30% of rural households have no paid 
employment. Salaries are paid in kind, either inputs (used on  household plots) or food, usually 
wheat.  Most  rural  families  rely  heavily  on  their  household  land  plots  of  about  0.1  ha,  which 
typically  account  for  more  than  half  of  total  income.  Consequently,  these  plots  have  become 
efficient  integrated  food  production  systems  contributing  about  40%  of  total  agricultural 
production. 
 
As  the  rural  economy  collapsed,  the  provision  of  social  services  also  went  into  steep 
4. 
decline.  The  former  state  and  collective  farms,  which  had  been  responsible  for  supporting 
primary  education  and  health  services  as  well  as  rural  water  supplies,  were  no  longer  able  to 
fund  them.  The  incidence  of  many  serious  diseases,  such  as  tuberculosis,  typhoid,  and 
intestinal infections, has increased substantially. A similar situation prevails in education . Also, 
most water supply systems are defunct and many rural communities depend on surface water 
for their domestic needs with the inevitable risk of infection. Less than 2% of the households are 
connected to sewerage systems. 
 
5. 
Against this background it is inevitable that poverty is widespread; nationally, 83% of the 
population had spending below the poverty threshold of TJS20/month. Poverty levels in the rural 
areas are even higher, rising to 89% in Khatlon region. The principal cause of poverty is the lack 
of job opportunities or very low salaries arising from the low productivity of irrigated agriculture. 
In  2000,  productivity  levels  plunged  to  less  that  half  of  those  of  1990.  The  Government  has

6. 
Tajikistan  remains  a  predominantly  agricultural  economy.  The  sector  contributes  about 
20%  of  gross  domestic  product,  30%  of  export  revenues  (mostly  cotton),  and  35%  of  tax 
revenues.  It  also  provides  the  major  source  of  employment.  Almost  80%  of  Tajikistan’s  arable 
area is irrigated. Consequently, issues relating to the irrigation have a very significant impact on 
agriculture and  on  the  economy  as  a  whole.  Given  the  Tajikistan  agro-climatic conditions, the 
Government and the farmers consider cotton as the most important cash crop. Its profitability in 
the recent past has, however, been reduced mainly because of (i) low productivity resulting from 
dysfunctional  irrigation  and  drainage  systems  and  inappropriate  use  of  crop  inputs,  and  (ii) 
decline in international prices. Local consumption of the cotton is only 30%, mainly in the textile 
and garment industry. Currently, there is little interest in developing the downstream industry to 
increase domestic consumption. 
 
7. 
Since  independence,  the  Government  has  initiated  a  range  of  reforms  intended  to 
transform the agriculture sector into a competitive market-led economy. The state procurement 
system  for  agricultural  commodities  was  dismantled  together  with  direct  administrative 
interventions  in  input  and  output  markets.  Price  controls  were  removed  and  trade  barriers 
relaxed. Land reform is ongoing within a framework, that allows private farms to operate based 
on  lifelong  inheritable  leases.  Payment  for  irrigation  water  delivery  has  been  introduced  and 
efforts  are  being  made  toward  the  full  recovery  of  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  of 
irrigation  systems.  The  implementation  of  these  reforms  has,  however,  not  been  satisfactory 
particularly because of interventions by local administrations.  
 
8. 
The reforms have brought only modest gains compared to the scale of the losses to the 
economy  since  independence.  The  current  cultivated  area  (irrigated  and  rainfed)  is  around 
710,000  hectares  (ha),  which  is  a  reduction  of  about  17%  over  the  past  decade.  Farms  have 
accumulated  debts  over  the  last  6  years  mainly  because  of  (i)  low  productivity  of  the  sector, 
particularly  of  cotton  because  of  deterioration  of  irrigation  and  drainage  facilities,  absence  of 
rural  support  services,  and  inappropriate  use  of  credit;  and  (ii)  low  prices  of  cotton  in  the 
international market. Cotton yields across the country average 1.4 tons (t)/ha compared to 2.8 
t/ha before independence. Cereal yields are also low, averaging 1.3 t/ha in 2000 compared to 
1990  yield  of  1.4  t/ha.  These  shifts  have  resulted  in  marked  changes  in  output.  In  2000, 
Tajikistan produced only 335,000 t cotton compared to over 800,000 t in 1990. These declines 
in sector performance are connected with wider key problems described in next section. 
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

9. 
Land  Reform  and  Farm  Reorganization.  Land  remains  state  owned.  Families  either 
individually or collectively are given land-use rights, which can be passed on through inheritance 
but  are  not  tradable.  These  limitations  restrict  the  evolution  of  commercial  agriculture.  Further 
steps are needed to broaden and deepen land-use rights. The lack  of clear procedures under 
the existing Law on Dehkan Farms4 adopted in 1992 for land allocation to private farmers and 
for dispute settlement has resulted in the decisions of local authorities being viewed as arbitrary, 
sometimes  involving  unfair  elements.  To  remove  these  flaws,  the  Parliament  amended  the

10. 
Agricultural  Marketing  and  Farm  Debts.  By  the  end  of  1996,  Tajikistan  had  officially 
abolished  production  targets  and  administered  pricing  for  all  agricultural  commodities.  These 
reforms  were  followed  by  the  privatization  of  all  23  state-owned  cotton  ginneries  after 
dismantling  of  barriers  to  private  sector  entry  into  the  cotton  ginning  and  wheat  flour  milling 
industries. Since 1997, cotton has suffered from a nearly 30% fall in world cotton prices. This fall 
has exacerbated the task of repaying commercial loans that were provided by Agroinvest Bank 
used to fund cotton production and were guaranteed by the Government. The total commercial 
debt  of  the  industry  including  working  capital  is  about  $120  million  spread  across  most  of  the 
larger farms. The major effort launched to clear this debt includes requiring the farms with debt 
to  plant  70%  of  their  land  to  cotton  (through  so  called  “cotton  balances”),  and  to  enter  into 
forward  purchasing  contracts  with  the  creditors  (called  investors,  generally  one  specified  by 
local  administration  for  each  district)  who  are  providing  inputs  (fertilizer  and  fuel)  at  above-
market  prices.  Farms  without  debt  are  also  under  pressure  by  local  administrations  to  grow 
cotton, but are free to sell their product to local textile factories. The export of raw cotton is not 
permitted and export of cotton fiber is, effectively, a monopoly. This situation is placing a heavy 
burden on rural communities in general and particularly upon the managers and employees of 
indebted farms. Details on cotton sector issues are in Appendix 3. 
 
11. 
Based  on  policy  discussions  during  loan  processing,  the  Government  issued  two 
Presidential decrees in September 2002 that exempted the 2002 cotton crop from value added 
tax and abolished cotton balances. This has reduced regional and district administrations’ roles 
in making decisions regarding cotton production, terminated the monopoly of Agroinvest Bank, 
and given farmers a free choice on investors thus facilitating competition among investors. Also, 
according to an earlier resolution, the farmers can now trade raw cotton. With the policy reforms 
agreed with the external funding agencies, particularly the World Bank, and those implemented 
recently,  the  policy  environment  is  conducive  to  improvements  in  agriculture  sector  through 
infrastructure  rehabilitation  and  capacity  building  interventions.  However  effective  coordination 
is needed among funding agencies to monitor the implementation of the reforms.

13.  Water  Management  Issues.  Agricultural  production  in  Tajikistan  dependents  cruically 
on irrigation, without which  the land has little production potential. Extensive irrigation systems, 
mostly built during the time of the former Soviet Union, cover nearly half the country’s relatively 
flat  land.  The  irrigation  and  associated  drainage  systems  are  rapidly  deteriorating  due to  poor 
management during the civil war and the lack of  O&M.  About  a  third  of  the  irrigated  area  use 
pumps to lift water from a few meters to over 300 m involving a cascade of pumping stations. 
About 75,000 ha of command area require water to be pumped at least 150 m. However, only 
60%  of  pumping  capacity  is  operational  with  a  corresponding  decline  in  irrigation  volumes.  A 
similar situation applies to the drainage systems; their neglect is leading to higher groundwater 
levels, water logging, and salinization. According to the agreement among the countries of the 
Aral Sea basin, enough water is allocated to serve Tajikistan’s irrigation systems. However, the 
water is not being adequately used because of dysfunctional irrigation systems and poor water 
management. Improving the performance of irrigated agriculture requires rehabilitating irrigation 
and drainage systems and more efficient water management. 
 
14. 
The rehabilitation of irrigation and drainage systems is inextricably linked to the issue of 
cost recovery and the maintenance of such relatively expensive systems. Water charges were 
introduced in 1996 and collection rates average less than 40% of billed amounts, but even if the 
charges were fully introduced and collected, they would cover only about 10% of maintenance 
costs,  excluding  energy  costs.  In  addition,  water  charges  do  not  differentiate  between  gravity 
and pump irrigation systems. The structure of irrigation water charges need to be rationalized to 
reflect differences in system costs; the basic water delivery fee should be increased to at least 
maintain its real value and collection rates must be improved substantially. The Government is 
committed  under  an  ongoing  World  Bank  project5  to  gradually  increase  recovery  rates  of  the 
water  delivery  cost  over  10  years  and  to  provide  funds  to  make  up  the  shortfall  during  the 
transition period. 
 
15. 
The  recently-approved  Water  Code  provides  a  basis  for  the  formation  of  water  users’ 
associations (WUAs) that will be responsible for O&M of the tertiary systems and contribute to 
the  cost  of  maintaining  the  secondary  and  primary  systems  through  water  charges  payable  to 
the local water agencies. This calls for an increased sense of partnership between WUAs and 
water  management  agencies.  The  Ministry  of  Water  Resources  and  Land  Reclamation 
(MWRLR) needs assistance to review its institutional capacity and structure in order to meet the 
impending requirements. 
 
16. 
Agriculture  Support  Services.  Many  newly-organized  dehkan  farms  with  limited 
farming knowledge would benefit from a program of farm demonstrations designed to illustrate 
the  technologies  that  could  dramatically  increase  their  productivity.  Farmers  using  relatively 
expensive  irrigation  water  need  to  learn  how  to  (i)  improve  crop  yields, (ii) intensify their crop 
rotations,  and  (iii)  diversify  their  cropping  to  achieve  higher  revenues.  Three  areas  of  support 
have been identified: (i) farm demonstration activities related to soil fertility and crop husbandry,

establishing farm machinery units (FMUs) and running them on commercial basis.

the civil conflict and lack of maintenance, most rural potable water networks have deteriorated,

A. 

Expected Impacts 

1. 

Financial and Economic Analyses 

58. 
Economic and financial analyses were carried out to justify the economic viability of the 
Project and financial viability of the participating farms. Economic analysis was carried out for 
the core components, which include irrigation and drainage improvements,  agricultural support 
services, and associated institutional support. The main quantifiable benefits of the investment 
come from the reversal of production decline and increased crop yields and cropping intensity. 
A similar analysis for the potable water supply component has not been carried out due to the 
nature  and  size  of  the  investment,  and  lack  of  a  reliable  database.  Public  health  statistics  are 
distorted  and  unreliable,  which  might  have  provided  a  basis  for  estimating  the  costs  of 
waterborne diseases, and the costs of possible interventions can only be roughly approximated 
without  reference  to  the  hydrological  conditions  of  specific  sites.  The  Project  has  adopted  a 
least-cost approach in selecting the potable water supply systems to be reconstructed. 
 
59. 
Quantifiable  benefits  will  accrue  basically  from  increases  in  agricultural  production, 
which  will  be  an  accumulative  effect  of  increases  in  yields,  cultivated  areas,  and  cropping 
intensity.  These  improvements  will  result  from  a  higher  level  of  and  dependable  irrigation 
supplies,  better  drainage,  and  adoption  of  improved  technologies.  The  average  cotton  yield  is 
expected to increase from 1.5 to 2.4 t/ha and wheat from 1.2 to 2.0 t/ha. Under the Project, the 
cropping  intensity  is  expected  to  increase  from  current  of  100%  to  121%.  Annual  cotton 
production in the project area is expected to increase from 66,909 to 131,812 t and wheat from 
42,917 to 69,758 t until year 9 and stabilize thereafter. 
 
60. 
The Project’s economic internal rate of return (EIRR) has been estimated at 22.9% with 
an economic net present value of $29.1 million. The sensitivity analysis was conducted to test 
the effect of key factors of economic viability. Overall, the Project’s EIRR was rather robust to 
adverse  effects  of  price  and  yield  declines,  project  benefit  delays,  and  investment  cost 
increases,  producing  in  all  cases  the  EIRR  considerably  higher  than  the  acceptable  minimum 
(12%). Also, to illustrate the financial viability of farms in the project area, indicative farm models 
for a large non-dehkan (1,400 ha) and a dehkan farm (17 ha) were developed for each of the 
three  project  areas.  Significant  project  impacts  are  expected  on  both  large  (non-dehkan) and 
small  (dehkan)  farms.  The  net  farm  incomes  are  projected  to  increase  until  year  9,  then  to 
stabilize. By year 9, the large farms are estimated to make a net annual income of $186-260/ha, 
and  small  farms  $190-300/ha.  Details  of  the  financial  and  economic  analyses  are  given  in 
Appendix 9 and detailed tables are given in Supplementary Appendix H.

Impact on Living Standards 

a. 

Poverty Reduction 

62.  While the main beneficiaries of the Project will be those directly involved in the dehkan 
farms and the collective farms that will be restructured in the project areas, the benefits accruing 
from the Project will redound to the poor residing in these areas. The widespread nature of rural 
poverty  in  the  project  sites  suggests  that  poverty  reduction  can  be  achieved  even  without  a 
focus on specific vulnerable social groups in society. Of the total 471,500 rural population in the 
project area, about 88% are below the poverty line, and most of them have garden plots for their 
subsistence  requirements  and  have  access  to  irrigation.  For  households  with  inadequate 
irrigation,  improved  irrigation  will  enable  them  to  increase  their  cropping  intensity  to  two  or,  in 
exceptional cases, three crops in a year and increase in yields by at least 20%. Among the poor 
households  with  average  spending  of  TJS10-20/family/month  (45%  of  the  total  estimated 
number  of  project  beneficiaries),  improved  productivity  and  incomes  will  be  sufficient  to  move 
them  out  of  poverty.  For  the  extremely  poor  (43%  of  project beneficiaries), improved yields in 
their  homestead  plots  will  augment  their  meager  food  resources.  Returns  to  farm  labor  will 
likewise increase, with greater positive impact on the dehkan farms. With improved production, 
wage  payments  of  farm  workers  will  stabilize,  hence  reducing  the  uncertainties  arising  from 
irregular pay schedule. Intensive cropping practices will raise person-day requirements for farm 
labor and increase demand for casual work by 10-15%. In sum, the Project’s prospective impact 
will  be  to  reduce  poverty  incidence  from  the  present  88%  to  43%.12  Impoverished  people, 
constituting about 4% of those in the project area, will be greatly benefited by the food-for-work 
scheme (para. 46). The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is given in Appendix 10.

Present  legislation  allows farmers  to  grow  the  crop  of  their  choice;  there  are  no  state 
orders.  In  practice,  cotton  production  remains  highly  controlled,  especially  at  the  local  level. 
Local  administrations,  if  necessary,  are  able  to  ensure  that  a  given  area  grows  cotton  and 
allocate resources and inputs to the specific farms. 

B. 

Production, Processing, and Marketing 

3. 
Tajikistan  was  a  major  suppliers  of  cotton  fiber  to  the  former  Soviet  economy.  After 
independence in 1991 and the collapse of the command economy,  Tajikistan’s cotton lost both 
its  market  and  source  of  financing  of  production. To  keep  cotton production,  the Government 
provided  direct  credit  to  the  state  farms,  through  the  National  Bank  of  Tajikistan.  The practice 
was obviously not sustainable due to the country’s weak fiscal capacity, and was terminated in 
1996  according  to  the  agreement  with  the  International  Monetary  Fund.  In  1997,  the 
Government  entered  into  an  agreement  to  borrow  and  guarantee  a  syndicated  loan  from  a 
banking consortium led by Credit Suisse First Boston with the support of P. Reinhart, the world’s 
second largest cotton trader. This was augmented by credits from other foreign financiers and 
joint venture trading companies. Reinhart  has  a  majority  shareholding  in  Tajikistan’s principal 
agriculture bank, Agroinvest, which channels the funds to cotton growers through a number of

C. 

Farm Debt 

6. 
Profitability of cotton declined  significantly  in  the  recent  years, due to  low  international 
market  prices  and  low  yields  resulting  from  untimely  and  inadequate  inputs,  inadequate 
irrigation  supplies,  soil  salinization,  and  a  high  water  table  because  of  poor  drainage.  The 
original  syndicated  loan  of  $60  million  that  the  Government  borrowed  in  1997  from  an 
international  banking  consortium  (para.  3)  was  not  fully  repaid  and  has  since  become  an 
annually rolled over financing facility for cotton production. The outstanding debt to this facility 
grew  appreciably  during  1997-1999  but  the  rate  of  increase  has  moderated  over  the  past  2 
years.  

The  cotton  crop  requires  about  $65  million  annually  in  working  capital,  of  which  about 
7. 
8% is estimated to come from farmers own resources. Thus farmers need to borrow about $60 
million annually in working capital. The cost of funds to Agroinvest Bank is about LIBOR+8% or 
approximately  10%  at  current  interest  rates.  Agroinvest  Bank  lends  to  the  local  investor 
companies at interest rates of 12%/annum. The local investors do not charge a specific margin 
but  use  several  mechanisms  to  cover  their  administration  and  funding  costs,  including  a 
commission on the provision of inputs, control of ginning margins, and control of the amount of 
fiber returned or assigned to the farmer. 

8. 
This financing system is extremely expensive for the farmer who remains the beneficiary 
of  last  resort.  In  effect,  the  producer  is  at  the  end  of  a  financing  chain,  which  ensures  that  all 
those  involved  are  paid  before  the  producer.  As  a  result  of  low  yields  and  low  international 
cotton prices, there are not sufficient resources in the system to enable everyone to achieve a 
reasonable  return  on  their  investment.  Consequently,  farms  are  accumulating  debt.  About 
20,000 t of cotton, which is about 3-4% of the production at state and collective farms, remains 
unharvested because of the lack of farm machinery and incentives among workers. The annual 
cotton  subsector  revenues  in  2001  were  approximately  $111.2  million  based  on  that  year’s 
cotton  output  and  prices.  From  this  amount,  a  total  of  $54.2  million  is  claimed  by  creditors, 
including  interest  on  debt.  This  leaves  a  residual  amount  of  $57.0  million  to  cover  all  farm 
production  costs.  However,  the  total  amount  of  finance  used  by  cotton  growers  in  2001  is 
estimated  at  $65.0  million,  leaving  a  deficit  of  about  $8.0  million  or  $30/ha  of  cotton.  These 
figures relate to a relatively good production year when the average cotton yield was 1.8 t/ha. In 
previous years, average yields have been as low as 1.3 t/ha. Thus, the explanation for the debt 
is a combination of factors, the most important of which is the relatively low productivity levels. 
An  average  yield  of  2.5  t/ha  instead  of  1.8  t/ha  would  enable  the  subsector  to  become  self-
financing. However, this is almost a 50% increase in productivity. To achieve this will require a 
major  investment  and  significant  structural  changes  within  the  agriculture  sector.  The  current 
situation is also influenced by low world cotton prices and the high cost of funds to the farmer. 

9. 
The cost of finance to the farmer is difficult to assess precisely, but it is estimated to be 
in  the  region  of  21%  annual  interest  rate  in  dollar  terms  after  allowing  for  all  charges  and 
commissions.  Farmers  generally  complain  of  late  delivery  of  agricultural  inputs,  particularly 
fertilizers, and delays in payments for labor, particularly for cotton picking, which is due after the 
investors  take  possession  of  the  produce  and  are,  therefore,  least  concerned  to  pay. With the

D. 

A Plan for Recovery 

At  the  Government’s  request,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  arranged  in 
12. 
Dushanbe  on  8  and  9  October  2002  the  Roundtable  on  Farm  Debts  and  Farm  Investment 
Opportunities.  A large number of  stakeholders, including farmers, local authorities, investors, 
central  government  officials,  nongovernmental  organization  and  external  funding  agencies, 
participated in the discussions. 

13. 
Candid  and  open  discussions  among  the  stakeholders,  conducted  for  the  first  time  in 
Tajikistan, resulted in identification of number of problem areas. These included:  (i) inadequate, 
and  sometimes  unfair  contracts  executed  between  investors  and  farmers,  both  of  which  often 
lack  crucial  financial/business  management  capacities;  (ii)  lack  of  a  clear  farm  privatization 
policy, particularly relating to transfer of accumulated farm debts; (iii) lack of alternative rural and 
micro credit facilities; (iv) inadequacy of the existing collateral law, which does not allow trading 
of the land-use certificate, and as a result, severely constrains the credit-worthiness of farms; (v) 
and the decreasing  yield  and  increasingly  erratic  and  uncertain  irrigation  water  supply  due  to 
deteriorating irrigation systems. 

Stakeholders’ discussions resulted in several general agreements, including (i) the need 
14. 
to  writeoff  or  reschedule  debts  to  Government  agencies,  such  as  utility  bills;  (ii)  the  need  to 
negotiate  with  investors  to  reschedule  the  accumulated  debts  based  on  mutually  agreed 
business  and  farm  production  plans,  which  need  to  be  prepared  for  each  farm;  (iii)  capacity 
building for improved farm management and stricter financial management  of heavily indebted 
farms; (iv) measures to accelerate production increases for farms without heavy debts; and (v) 
promotion of public awareness of farmers’ rights and available options to modify the production 
contracts, including provision of preproduction credit in cash, sale of raw cotton, etc.

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES 

A. 

Introduction 

Economic and financial analyses were carried out to justify the economic viability of the 
1. 
Project  and  financial  viability  of  the  participating  farms.  In  general,  comparisons  of  costs  and 
benefits in the  analysis  of  projects  are  made  on  the  basis  of  quantifiable  physical  inputs  and 
outputs.  Incremental  net  benefits  are  estimated,  where  possible,  on  the  basis  of  the  changes 
expected to occur and other conditions expected to prevail within targeted geographic areas (i) 
in  the  absence  of  the  proposed  project’s  interventions,  and  (ii)  as  a  consequence  of 
implementing  the  proposed  interventions.  For  the  economic  analysis  these  quantifiable  inputs 
and  outputs  are  valued  according  to  their  border  price  equivalents. For the financial analysis, 
established prices are applied as determined by local markets. 

2. 
The  principal  objective  of  the  economic  analysis  is  to  establish  whether  proposed 
investments  are  profitable  for  the  economy  as  a  whole,  which  is  determined  when  the  net 
present  value  of  costs  and  benefits  are  positive  when  discounted  at  the  opportunity  cost  of 
capital. 

3. 
The  irrigation  component  particularly  lends  itself  to  quantitative  analysis  based  on  the 
expected performance of agricultural production dependent upon the infrastructure of the three 
schemes under consideration. In addition to farm level costs, the project costs associated with 
infrastructure rehabilitation, agricultural machinery services, support to establishments of water 
users’  associations  and  project  management  and  monitoring  costs  have  been  included  in  the 
economic  and  financial  analysis.  For  the  whole  project  analysis,  crop  and  area-wide  farm 
budgets have been estimated for each proposed scheme, then aggregated at the project level.  

4. 
The economic analysis has been carried out in two stages. The first stage is concerned 
with  the  economic  viability  of  selected  crops  in  two  settings,  one  without  the  project  and  the 
other with project interventions. These are assessed using economic crop budgets for the two 
situations. The second stage is the determination of the economic internal rate of return (EIRR). 
This requires the aggregation of the results of the budgetary analyses weighted according to the 
projected  cropping  patterns.  The  EIRR  of  the  Project  is  based  on  the  incremental  benefits 
resulting from project interventions. 

5. 
A  similar  analysis  of  the  potable  water  supply  component  is  not  possible  due  to  the 
nature  of  the  activity  and  the  data  available  for  an  assessment.  Not  only  are  public  health 
statistics distorted and unreliable, which might have provided a basis for estimating the costs of 
waterborne  diseases,  the  costs  of  possible  interventions  themselves  can  only  be  roughly 
approximated  without  reference  to  the  hydrological  conditions  of  specific  sites.  The  best 
approach in this case is to present a least-cost argument that, given the information available at 
the time of the preparation, the proposed investment options in terms of cost per beneficiary are 
comparable to norms of similar water supply investments elsewhere.

The  total  project  area  in  the  three  regions  covers  approximately  85,000  ha  of  irrigated 
land  and  has  approximately  471,500  beneficiaries.  The  two  major  crops  in  the  project  area—

On  the  remaining  11%  of  irrigated  cropland,  several  minor  crops  including  fodder,  vegetables, 
and  fruits  are  planted.  Depending  on  particular  regions  and  individual  irrigation  systems,  the 
current  crop  yields  in  the  project  area  vary  considerably:  for  cotton,  between  0.7  and  1.8  tons 
(t)/ha and for wheat, 0.8 and 2.0 t/ha. 

C. 

Major Assumptions 

Many  large  farms  in  the  project  area  are  unprofitable  and  have  significant  debt,  partly 
8. 
due to their inability to repay production loans. With the resolution of debts, the large farms are 
likely to reorganize into dehkan farms able to make their own farming decisions. The Project will 
facilitate  resolution  of  the  debts  and  the  reorganization  process  and  thereby  creating  equal 
opportunities for land allocations. 

9. 
Many farms, particularly the large ones, have been unprofitable in recent years caused 
by  (i)  declining  crop  productivity  due  to  deteriorating  conditions  of  the  irrigation  and  drainage 
systems, (ii) multiple and high taxes, and (iii) low and unstable prices for their crops.  

10.  With the Project, crop yields are expected to increase progressively for 9 years: (i) cotton 
from 1.5 to 2.4 t/ha, (ii) wheat from 1.2 to 2.0 t/ha. Without the Project, crop yields are expected 
to decline to 1.2 t/ha for cotton and 1.0 t/ha for wheat. In addition, a significant loss in irrigated 
area is expected under the without the Project The projected yield improvements are relatively 
modest  since  the  rehabilitation  will  focus  on  improving  of  primary  and  secondary  canals. 
However, since the Project will be providing agricultural support services on 6,000 ha on a pilot 
basis, the projected yield increases are expected to be modest and to take effect gradually. No 
yield  improvements  are  assumed  until  year  5,  when  many  of  the  rehabilitation  works  will  be 
complete. 

11.  With the Project, the cropping intensity is expected to increase from 100% to 121%. This 
assumption varies between subproject sites, depending on the current situation and feasibility of 
future  irrigation.  For  instance,  with  the  Project,  the  cropping  intensity  in  Khojabakirgan  is 
expected to increase by 31%, in Vakhsh by 15% and in Kyzylsu-Yakhsu by 13%. 

12.  Without the Project, the current levels of inputs are likely to continue to be used over an 
essentially declining areas of adequately irrigated land and the cost of energy will remain at its 
current low level. However, with the Project, the farmers are expected to increase their use of 
fertilizers and adopt integrated pest management techniques. With the Project, the introduction 
of short-season varieties of oilseeds, maize, and pulses will encourage the growing of two crops 
per year where the water resources are adequate. These crops are grown already on household 
plots and on some farms but the varieties are old and not suitable for more intensive cropping 
systems.  The  introduction  of  better  varieties  with  shorter  growing  seasons  will  produce  more 
balanced  crop  rotations  and  will  provide  an  opportunity  for  farms  to  increase  incomes  to  help 
meet the increased cost of irrigation system operation and maintenance (O&M).

Based on the analytical models developed to assess the performance of the Project in

have  greater  share  of  wheat  than  large  farms,  since  many  dehkan  farms  operate  on  a 
subsistence basis and prefer food crops. In addition, yields per hectare of cotton and wheat on a

intensive on-farm trials on improvements of soil and water management and introduction of new 
seeds.  Also,  fixed  and  overhead  costs  at  dehkan  farms  are  expected  to  be  15%  lower  than 
those  at  large  farms,  since  the  former  do  not  entail  huge  management  and  other  costs  that 
typical large farms involve.

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

The  Government  and  ADB  are

Agreement:  
 
The Government has set poverty reduction as its primary objective for sustainable development. 
It has finalized its national poverty reduction strategy, which was endorsed by the Parliament on 24 June 
2002.  The  strategy  will  focus  on  (i)  accelerated,  socially  fair,  labor-intensive,  and  export-oriented 
economic  growth;  (ii)  efficient  and  fair  provision  of  basic  social  services;  (iii)  targeted  support  to  the 
poorest groups of the population; and (iv) efficient governance and improvement in security. Agriculture 
sector  development  that  emphasizes  improving  productivity  and  creating  jobs  has  a  key  role  in  the 
strategy’s  pro-poor  growth  intervention.  The  high  priority  accorded  to  agriculture  sector  development  is 
warranted  as  about  four-fifths  of  the  poor  population  reside  in  the  countryside  and  most  rural  residents 
depend on farming as their main income and food source.  
 
The poverty reduction strategy likewise accords equal attention to addressing nonincome-based 
poverty.  Less  than  one-fourth  of  total  rural  households  have  piped  drinking  water;  many  obtain  their 
water from open ditches, thus increasing their susceptibility to waterborne diseases. Only 2% of the rural 
communities are connected to sewerage systems. Thus, the poverty reduction strategy, having adopted 
the  Millennium  Development  Goals,  has  set  as  a  target  that,  by  2010,  80%  of  the  total  households  will 
have access to safe water. 
 
Improving 
productivity  and  facilitating  diversification  of  the  economic  structure  particularly  in  the  agriculture  sector 
have been identified as major areas for poverty reduction in the short and medium terms. Another focal 
area is the provision of potable water especially in the rural areas. For both areas of intervention, targets 
will be set and monitored periodically to ensure their significant impact on  poverty. 
 
Contribution of the Sector/Subsector to Reduce Poverty in Tajikistan: 
 
Tajikistan  is  predominantly  an  agriculture  economy  as  the  sector  contributes  20%  of  gross 
domestic  product,  30%  of  export  revenues,  and  more  than  half  of  total  employment.  Almost 80% of the 
total arable land is irrigated.  
 
There  are  at  least  two  ways  that  agriculture  development  will  make  significant  inroads  in 
combating  poverty  in  the  country.  First,  improved  productivity  and  more  efficient  irrigation  systems  will 
translate to higher outputs and increased incomes of the rural poor. At present, about three-fifths of the 
population  live  in  rural  areas  and  rely  primarily  on  production  of  their  irrigated  garden  plots  (averaging 
0.1-0.2 hectare [ha]/household) as their main source of food and some cash income. These subsistence 
plots,  together  with  the  small-sized  private-owned  (dehkan)  farms  contribute  about  40%  of  total 
agriculture production. 
 
However,  total  production  and  productivity  in  all  farms  have  been  low.  Total  output  of  the 
agriculture sector on average is just 55% of the 1991 output level and the yield in 2000 was 44% of the 
1991  yield  level.  For  the  poor  who  subsist  mainly  on  their  small  garden  plots,  lack  of  irrigation  and 
access to new farm practices have limited their cropping intensity to the spring months, thus preventing 
them from additional cash income during the winter season. Moreover, because of the poor performance 
of  the  agriculture  sector,  wage  laborers  in  the  sector,  who  are  also  poor,  suffer.  Their  wages  have 
deteriorated in real terms; and payments of their salaries have frequently been delayed. In 2001, arrears 
in the agriculture sector were highest across sectors at TJS11.0 million. 
 
The  second  contribution  of  the  sector  to  reducing  poverty  is  by  creating jobs. At least 30% of 
rural households are unemployed. Moreover, because of the civil strife, 18% of the total households are 
female-headed.  With  the  limited  creation  of  formal  sector  employment,  overseas  work  and  jobs  in  the 
informal sector are the next best alternative. Improved productivity in agriculture that expands labor use 
and  diversify  crop  use  will  be  more  economically  and  socially  sustainable.  More  jobs  and  increasing 
incomes  in  the  agriculture  sector  spur  rural  industries  that  in  turn,  form  the  base  for  rural 
industrialization;  in-country  (as  opposed  to  overseas)  employment  reduces  the  potentials  for  family  and 
cultural breakdowns.

Poverty Analysis:  Proposed Classification - Core Poverty Intervention 

Increased  and  improved  access  to  safe  drinking  water  and  better  sanitation  practices  will 
 
contribute  significantly  to  addressing  non-income  poverty.  Infectious  and  parasitic  diseases  (especially 
those that are waterborne) are the second leading causes of deaths in the country and disproportionally 
affect  the  poor.  Provision  of  safe  drinking  water  and  education  on  good  sanitation  practices  focus  on 
improving the health conditions of the poor and vulnerable groups and lessening the burden for women 
and children in fetching water. 
 
B. 
 
In  the  project  areas  in  Khatlon  and  Sughd,  the  poverty  incidence  is  higher  than  the  national 
 
average  of  83%.  About  89%  of  the  rural  populace  in  Khatlon  region  and  87%  in  Sughd  region  are 
considered  poor,  with  average  monthly  spending  of  below  TJS20/family/month.  In  the project area, the 
incidence of poverty is estimated at 88%. Among these poor, about 45% are considered very poor with 
expenditures  of  TJS10-20/family/month.  The  Project  is  expected  to  increase  the  incomes  of  this  group 
so that their spending will be more  than  TJS20/month  and  thus  they  will  be  pulled  out  of  poverty.  The 
remaining 43% are extremely poor. with expenditures less than TJS10/family/month. Income sources of 
the rural populace are partly from farm wages (16% of their total income) but most rely on farming both 
for subsistence and for sale (63%); a few households received remittances from their close kin working 
outside  the  region  or  augment  their  household  income  through  occasional  public  works  activities  and 
cotton harvesting. Women and children from poor households are employed on a voluntary basis during 
the cotton harvesting season. The poor especially in Khatlon depend mainly on their household crops for 
their  food,  with  hardly  any  marketable  surplus  left.  Most  of  the  rural  populace  in  these  regions employ 
coping  strategies  for  survival  such  as  shifting  to  cheaper  food  stuffs,  decreasing  the  number  of  daily 
meals,  and  decreasing  the  amount  of  food  consumed.  These  have  led  to  declines  in  per  capita  daily 
caloric  intake  and  inadequate  family  nutrition.  Other  coping  strategies  include  the  selling  of  assets, 
borrowing,  and  migrating  to  other  regions  and  outside  the  country  for  work.  Partly  because  of  the  war 
and  due  to  out-migration  in  search  of  jobs,  as  many  as  25,000  families,  most  of  whom  are  found in the 
Khatlon  region,  have  female  heads  who  have  to  cope  with  rearing  their  children  and  of  finding  income 
and food for the family. 
 
Lack  of  income-  and  job-creating activities in the countryside, and the declining productivity of 
the  arable  lands  are  the  principal  causes  of  the  income-based  poverty.  Official  unemployment  in  the 
project  areas  is  11-18%  although  unofficial  estimates  peg  the  unemployment  rates  at  30%.  Moreover, 
the  deterioration  of  irrigation  facilities  combined  with  poor  farming  practices  (e.g.,  limited  use  of  high 
quality  seeds,  fertilizers,  chemicals,  and  farm  machinery)  has  resulted  in  decreasing  yields  of  major 
crops (cotton and wheat), and in lower cropping intensities. Cotton yields in the project areas are 0.7-1.8 
t/ha while wheat yields are 0.8-2.0 t/ha; both are less than half the 1990 levels. As a consequence, many 
of  the  farm  workers  in  the  large  farm  enterprises  have  declining  wages  and  delayed  payments.  For  the 
poor who subsist mainly on their small garden plots, lack of irrigation and access to new farm practices 
have  limited  their  cropping  intensity  to  the  spring  months,  thus  preventing  them  from  generating 
additional  cash  income  during  the  winter  season.  Low  incomes  induced  a  shift  to  consumption  of 
cheaper  foodstuffs  and  lower intake of protein, vitamins, and micronutrients, resulting into stunting and 
wasting problems among children and anemia among pregnant and lactating mothers.  
 
Poverty  in  the  project  areas  is  also  nonincome  based.  Limited  access  to  potable  water  topped 
the list of concerns among the households in the project areas. The poor in the project areas have the 
least access to potable water; and are more susceptible to waterborne diseases. In Khojabakirgan, only 
about  25%  of  people  have  access  to  water  supply  and  more  than  50%  obtain  their  water  from  open 
ditches, 33% from water pipes, and less than 5% buy water from tanker trucks. In the Khatlon region, the 
situation  is  more  severe  as  less  than  20%  have  access  to  water  supply  and  more  than  75%  of  the 
population obtain their water from open ditches such as irrigation canals. Some people walk as far as 10 
kilometers  to  collect  water  for  domestic  use;  in  Kyzylsu-Yakhsu, queuing for water takes as much as 6 
hours.  In  all  these  areas,  many  of  the  water  fetchers  are  children  and  women.  Because  of  the  poor 
quality  of  potable  water,  and  lack  of  knowledge  of  good  sanitation  practices,  a  large  proportion  of  the 
project’s  population  suffers  from  waterborne  diseases.  All  of  the  targeted  districts  have  incidence  rates 
of typhoid, dysentery, hepatitis, and malaria ranging from 130% to 230% of the national average.

A  stakeholder  analysis  was  conducted  during  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  and 
 
the  target  clientele  and  the  issues  to  be  addressed  was  verified  with  a  small  sample  of  stakeholders

surveys  at  village  levels)  and  qualitative  (focused  group  discussions,  stakeholder  workshop,  and 
consultation  meetings  and  dialogues)  approaches,  and  (ii)  secondary  and  primary  information  was 
employed to ensure that the issues and needs of the poor and vulnerable groups are properly identified; 
that  the  poor  will  benefit  disproportionately  from  the  investment  Project  in  a  sustainable  manner;  that 
gender,  environment,  and  other  social  issues  are  tackled;  and  that  the  prospective  beneficiaries  will  be 
actively  involved  in  implementing  and  monitoring  the  Project.  Also,  three  of  the  five  criteria  for  the 
selection of the investment project schemes were pro-poor focused (i) broad geographical coverage but 
with emphasis on the poorer districts, (ii) absence of safe drinking water source, and (iii) the willingness 
of local communities to participate.  
 
The  project  areas  cover  26  villages  with  a  total  rural  population  of  471,500,  the  primary 
beneficiaries  of  the  proposed  Project.  Of  total  beneficiaries,  45%  are  poor  (those  with  spending 
TJS10-TJS20/month), 40% are very poor (spending  of  TJS4-TJS10/month), and 3% are extremely poor 
with spending less than TJS4/month. The main vulnerable groups are (i) households with more than five 
children,  (ii)  single-headed  families  especially  those  headed  by  women,  (iii)  families  with  inadequate 
non-agriculture  employment,  (iv)  the  elderly,  and  (v)  members  of  dehkan  collective  farms  producing 
cotton.  Most  households  have  small  garden  plots  that  provide  their  main  source  of  income  and  food;  a 
few own livestock for additional food and income. Food is their largest expenditure. When asked during 
the group discussion what their priority needs are, the following were mentioned often: (i) lack of drinking 
water  facilities,  (ii)  poor  condition  of  irrigation  facilities;  (iii)  lack  of  jobs;  (iv)  high  rates  of  infectious 
diseases;  and  (v)  lack  of  access  to  agriculture  inputs  (fertilizers  and  seeds),  farm  equipment,  and 
updated  farming  practices.  Women  play  multiple  roles  at  the  household  level,  and  as  a  consequence, 
cannot  fully  participate  in  or  have  equal  access  to  information  and  technology,  and  land  tenure  rights. 
With  project  implementation,  intensive  farming  will  ensue  in  the  garden,  dehkan,  and  other  farm  types, 
resulting  in  increased  work  hours  for  women.  In  general,  women  farmers  consider  this  a  plus  factor 
because of the low incomes and job opportunities in the project areas.

Gender Analysis and Plan 

1. 
Gender  Status  and  Issues.     The  women  in  Tajikistan  bore  the  brunt  of  the  combined  adverse 
impact  of  the  country’s  transition  to  a  market  economy  and  the  5-year  civil  conflict,  which  ensued 
immediately  after  independence.  The  economic  and  social  difficulties  during  the  transition  years  have 
constrained  economic  activity  and,  in  turn,  intensified  women’s  workload  and  participation  in  both  the 
informal  sector  and  low-paying  formal  labor  market.  Women’s  limited  access  to  productive  and 
remunerative  resources  has  constrained  their  economic  opportunities,  and  especially  for  rural  women, 
has  confined  them  to  just  the  coping  strategies  for  survival.  Partly  because  of  the  war  and  due  to  out-
migration in search of jobs, as many as 25,000 families, the majority of them in the Khatlon region, have 
female  heads  who  have  to  cope  with  rearing  their  children  and  finding  income  and  food  for  the  family. 
Thus, to make ends meet, rural women play multiple roles. They farm intensively their garden plots, which 
provide  the  main  food  and  income  source  for  their  families.  If  they  have  some  savings,  the  women  buy 
some  livestock  and  take  care  of  these  animals.  They  are  also  responsible  for  marketing  any  surplus  in 
their  produce  as  well  as  planning  and  executing  the  household  budget.  Rural  women  are  the  bulk  of  the 
workforce during cotton and wheat harvesting. They are also responsible for taking care of the elderly and 
disabled.  
 
2. 
The women were adversely affected by the collapse of the social safety nets and social protection 
measures.  Much  of  these  roles  were  left  to  the  women  to  assume  in  their  homes,  which  effectively 
reduced  their  participation  in  social  and  political  groups  at  the  community  and  national  levels.  With  the 
closures  of  nurseries,  mothers  took  over  the  care  of  their  young  children.  Net  enrolment  of  girls  to  boys 
also  declined  dramatically,  especially  at  the  7-18  year  age  brackets. Taking care of the elderly and the

burden  of  fetching  drinking  water  from  open  ditches,  canals,  and  river  streams;  often  times,  they  walk  a 
far distance to obtain water.
